Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Situation2: They encounter a customer trying to return an item without a receipt and need to apply the store’s return policy.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the group chat with my stepfamily lighting up with messages about the big holiday dinner. My stepmom’s words echoed in my mind: “It would mean a lot if you were there. We’re all counting on you.” I knew how important it was to show up, to be part of the family, especially since I was still trying to fit in. But as I slipped on my work vest and clocked in at the store, my manager reminded me, “We’re short-staffed today. We need you here the whole shift.”

Midway through my shift, a woman approached my register, frustration written all over her face. She wanted to return a blender, but she didn’t have a receipt. Store policy was clear—no returns without proof of purchase. She pleaded, saying it was a gift and she needed the money for her own family’s holiday. My heart twisted. I wanted to help, but I also knew I could get in trouble for breaking the rules.

I glanced at the clock, knowing my shift would run late, making it impossible to get to the family dinner on time. My mind raced, torn between being the reliable step-sibling my family wanted and the responsible cashier my job demanded.
